channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: As Russians Retreat, Putin Is Criticized by Hawks Who Trumpeted His War
item.description: Russian bloggers reporting from the front line provide a uniquely less-censored view of the war. But as Russia’s military flails, these once vocal supporters are exposing its flaws, lies and all.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Juan Barreto/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A destroyed Russian military vehicle in Balakliya, in the eastern Kharkiv region, on Saturday.

item.title: How Ukraine Gained Momentum Against Russia and Took City of Izium
item.description: For months, Russia used the city of Izium as a way station to resupply and reinforce its troops in their campaign to seize the eastern Donbas region. With a northern offensive, Ukraine has retaken the city.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Juan Barreto/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A destroyed tank in Balakliya, in the Kharkiv region, on Saturday.

item.title: Queen’s Death Leaves UK Grappling With Its Sense of National Identity
item.description: A figure who embodied Britain, Elizabeth cast long shadow. She leaves behind a country unsettled by domestic crises and anxiety over its place in the world.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laying flowers outside Windsor Castle on Friday in tribute to Queen Elizabeth II.

item.title: King Charles III Is Formally Proclaimed to His New Role
item.description: Charles will spend much of the first 10 days of his reign leading his country in mourning the queen, whose state funeral will be held on Sept. 19 in Westminster Abbey.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Daniel Leal
item.media:description: In a ceremony filled with pomp and process at St. James’s Palace, a royal residence near Buckingham Palace, King Charles III was officially proclaimed on Saturday.

item.title: For Trump’s Lawyers, Legal Exposure Comes With the Job
item.description: The many lawyers who have helped the former president avoid removal from office and indictment have drawn legal problems of their own.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt and Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lawyers who have worked for former President Donald J. Trump face considerable legal exposure as the Justice Department carries out two overlapping investigations.

item.title: Justice Dept. and Trump Legal Team Clash Over Special Master Candidates
item.description: The two sides had sharply diverging views of who could serve as a special master and what that person would do.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Alan Feuer, Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Agents seized more than 11,000 government documents, including about 100 marked as classified, from Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trump’s residence in Palm Beach, Fla.

item.title: Jann Wenner Wants to Reveal It All
item.description: The Rolling Stone founder talks about LSD, not reading the magazine anymore and how the Stones now look like “Lord of the Rings” characters onstage.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: Dana Scruggs for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jann Wenner at his home in Montauk, N.Y., in August.

item.title: Carlos Alcaraz Is Favorite Against Casper Ruud in U.S. Open Men’s Singles Final
item.description: Sunday’s match is not only a battle for the U.S. Open men’s singles title. It will also determine the next world No. 1, and whoever wins will rise to the top spot for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times; Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Whoever wins will rise to the top spot for the first time: an unprecedented scenario in a major final since the ATP computer rankings were created in 1973.

item.title: Wall Street’s Favorite Sport Is a Failing Business
item.description: Tennis may appear to be on a roll, with exciting young players and record ratings. But if it were a company, activist shareholders would have already called for a restructuring.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch and Vivian Giang
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Casper Ruud during his semifinal victory at the U.S. Open on Friday.

item.title: Guaranteed Income Programs Spring Up City by City
item.description: Since 2020, four dozen pilot programs have started, with Los Angeles running one of the largest to provide cash assistance.
item.dc:creator: Kurtis Lee
item.media:credit: Adam Perez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alondra Barajas with her daughter, EliAnn, in the Chatsworth neighborhood of Los Angeles.

item.title: Medical Impact of Roe Reversal Goes Beyond Abortion Clinics, Doctors Say
item.description: State abortion bans carry narrow but sometimes vague exceptions, and years of prison time. That’s forcing doctors to think like lawyers, and hospitals to create new protocols.
item.dc:creator: Kate Zernike
item.category: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A hospital bed in the emergency department at the University of Wisconsin Hospital in Madison, Wis.

item.title: A Proud Nuclear Town Grapples With How to Remember the Bomb
item.description: The A high school in Richland, Wash., is emblazoned with a mushroom cloud. But some are asking for better ways to recognize the city’s history-altering past.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker and Mason Trinca
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times

item.title: The Case for Clover Lawns, the Environmentally Friendly Alternative to Grass
item.description: Amid droughts and extreme heat, people are welcoming clover into their lawns, an alternative to the purely grass lawn, helping them save water and money.
item.dc:creator: Anna P. Kambhampaty
item.media:credit: Amanda Mary for The New York Times
item.media:description: For homeowners trying to maintain pleasant lawns, clover can be a less expensive and more resilient alternative to grass.

item.title: Censorship Is the Refuge of the Weak
item.description: Republicans across the country are trying to use the power of the state to restrict speech.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Illustration by Rebecca Chew/The New York Times; photographs by chictype and Sezeryadigar, via Getty Images

item.title: Charles in Charge
item.description: No more women reign over the new king.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Bob Dear, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II followed by Princess Diana, the Princess of Wales and Prince Charles, the Prince of Wales, arrive for the State Opening of Parliament in London on Tuesday, Nov. 6, 1984.

item.title: The Ukraine War’s Decisive Season
item.description: We will soon see if European resolve holds up.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Dimitar Dilkoff/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Rudy Giuliani Is Alone
item.description: 9/11 was his triumph, then it became his undoing.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Kirtzman
item.media:credit: Robert F. Bukaty/Associated Press
item.media:description: As mayor of New York, Rudolph Giuliani led Gov. George Pataki and Senator Hillary Clinton on a tour of the site of the World Trade Center the day after the Sept. 11 attack in 2001.

item.title: Democrats Didn’t Conjure Up the Demand for MAGA Candidates
item.description: The Republican base has shown us what it wants, repeatedly.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times

item.title: The Royal Grief You Will Not See
item.description: To mourn in public is to feel judged but supported, too.
item.dc:creator: Patti Davis
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: John Sibley/Reuters
item.media:description: Britain’s King Charles III and Queen Camilla at Buckingham Palace.

item.title: How to Address the Child Therapist Shortage
item.description: Ways to make the work more sustainable for new and experienced therapists.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Bonanno
item.media:credit: Josie Norton

item.title: The Burn Test
item.description: Can controlled fires protect forests? California is about to find out.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Andri Tambunan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Margarita Rivera, a Ph.D. student at U.C. Irvine, using a drip torch during the prescribed burn.

item.title: Jennifer Egan and the Goon Squad
item.description: The novelist talks about her Pulitzer-winning book, which includes one chapter written as a PowerPoint presentation, and Stephen Fry discusses Greek mythology.

item.title: Are You in a Moral Quandary?
item.description: We’d like to discuss it with you, live on Twitter Spaces, with the magazine’s Ethicist columnist, Kwame Anthony Appiah. Let us know below what’s troubling you.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: In Premier League, Crisis Is a Constant
item.description: Change at Chelsea. A loss at Liverpool. Chaos is part and parcel of the Premier League story line. But it doesn’t have to be that way.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: Carl Recine/Pool Via Reuters
item.media:description: Thomas Tuchel, before the fall.

item.title: The Olive Oil Capital of the World, Parched
item.description: Spain’s Jaén Province, home to one fifth of the world’s supply of “green gold,” copes with climate change and threats to its way of life.
item.dc:creator: David Segal and José Bautista
item.media:credit: Emilio Parra Doiztua for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jaén, a province of Andalusia, has over 67 million olive trees.

item.title: Downsizing in Retirement: Expenses They Didn’t Expect
item.description: On the way to spending less, people often have to shell out more, at least temporarily — especially when selling a home. Here’s what to consider.
item.dc:creator: Susan B. Garland
item.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Louise Angel Kiss and her husband, Charles, moved to a retirement community in Issaquah, Wash., a few years ago. They weren’t able to sell their old home until they spent thousands of dollars renovating it.

item.title: For Florida A&M, Getting on the Field Is Just One of Many Problems
item.description: The university’s football players nearly skipped their opening game in protest of their mismanaged athletic department. Recent history shows far more dysfunction within the university’s sports program.
item.dc:creator: Billy Witz
item.media:credit: Malcolm Jackson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bragg Memorial Stadium in Tallahassee, Fla., is the home of Florida A&M football.

item.title: Gun Violence Epidemic Looms Over Swedish Election
item.description: The far right has made strides by tying the longstanding issue to immigration, while Sweden’s center-left party is blaming it on failed integration to fight an exceptionally tight race.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Amela Mahovic
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Susanna Yakes showing a stuffed animal that belonged to her daughter Adriana, who was 12 when she was shot and killed in Stockholm in 2020.

item.title: Can you get reinfected with monkeypox?
item.description: Experts weigh in on how long immunity lasts after an infection — or vaccination.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images

item.title: Why Can’t I Stand the Sound of Chewing? Misophonia, Explained
item.description: Misophonia, a little-known syndrome, is characterized by strong negative emotional reactions to certain sounds or visual cues.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Guillem Casasús

item.title: We Want to Hear About Your Experience With Egg Freezing
item.description: The Times is looking for stories from readers.
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times

item.title: The Power of a Casual Check-in Text
item.description: New research says most of us underestimate the power of the casual check-in.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.category: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
item.media:credit: Moritz Wienert

item.title: ’1776’ Musical Returns to Broadway With a Diverse Twist
item.description: A revival of the classic musical offers a fresh twist on the founding for the post-“Hamilton” era.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Camila Falquez for The New York Times
